thesis.description: In order to assess the relative distortability of the lungs and chest wall, we cannulated one lung in intact anesthetized dog and starting at different lung volumes (VL), inflated one lobe with known volume increments (+ΔVx) using positive pressure, leaving the other lobes free.to change volume (+ ΔVy), i.e. inflate or deflate. If the lung were very distortable (liquid-like) ΔVy would equal - ΔVx. If the chest wall were very disortable, ΔVy would equal zero. If neither were distortable, ΔAy would be very much greater than zero. At low VL, ΔVy max was -12.5% of ΔVx max. At high VL, ΔVy max was zero. Measured pleural surface pressure differences between lobes were large. Results indicate that; 1) lung distortabllity decreases as volume increases; 2) the pressure cost of chest wall deformations is substantial and results in marked regional differences in pleural surface pressures.
thesis.creator: Murphy, Brian G.
thesis.subject: Experimental Medicine.
thesis.title: Lung and chest wall distortability in dogs
